title: Fix: BC Cloud Restore â "No Paid License for Production Companies" Error
excerpt: When restoring a Business Central cloud production database into a Docker container, you may hit a license error blocking access. Here's the quick SQL fix.
body:
# Fix: BC Cloud Restore â "No Paid License for Production Companies" Error

When restoring a **Business Central cloud (production) database** into a Docker container, you may encounter:

> _"You cannot open the company because you do not have a paid license for production companies."_

This happens because the restored database has companies flagged as **Production**, which requires a specific license type that most ISV/dev licenses don't cover in Docker.

---

## Quick Fix â Mark Companies as Evaluation

Run the SQL update against your restored database inside the container, then restart it.

### Step 1: Update Company Flag

Replace `<ContainerName>` and `<DatabaseName>` with your values.

```powershell
docker exec -it <ContainerName> powershell -Command "Invoke-Sqlcmd -Query 'UPDATE [Company] SET [Evaluation Company] = 1' -Database '<DatabaseName>'"
```

**Example (used in this fix):**
```powershell
docker exec -it BC27-TestEnv powershell -Command "Invoke-Sqlcmd -Query 'UPDATE [Company] SET [Evaluation Company] = 1' -Database 'Production_20260222_02_Latest'"
```

> This updates **all** companies in the database. Your data is unaffected â only the company type metadata changes.

To target a **specific company** only:
```powershell
docker exec -it <ContainerName> powershell -Command "Invoke-Sqlcmd -Query `"UPDATE [Company] SET [Evaluation Company] = 1 WHERE [Name] = 'YourCompanyName'`" -Database '<DatabaseName>'"
```

### Step 2: Restart the Container

```powershell
Restart-BcContainer -containerName "<ContainerName>"
```

---

## Optional â Import / Verify Your ISV License

If the above alone doesn't resolve it, ensure your license is properly imported into the container:

```powershell
Import-BcContainerLicense -containerName "<ContainerName>" -licenseFile "C:\\path\\to\\your\\license.bclicense"
Restart-BcContainer -containerName "<ContainerName>"
```

---

## Diagnostic Query

To check the current company type before/after the fix:

```powershell
docker exec -it <ContainerName> powershell -Command "Invoke-Sqlcmd -Query 'SELECT [Name], [Evaluation Company] FROM [Company]' -Database '<DatabaseName>'"
```

- `Evaluation Company = 0` â Production (causes the error)
- `Evaluation Company = 1` â Evaluation (works with ISV/dev license)

---

## Summary

| Step | Command |
|------|---------|
| Fix all companies | `UPDATE [Company] SET [Evaluation Company] = 1` |
| Restart container | `Restart-BcContainer -containerName "..."` |
| Verify | `SELECT [Name], [Evaluation Company] FROM [Company]` |

title: Setting Up Business Central in Docker for Local Development

body:
# Setting Up Business Central in Docker for Local Development

Running Business Central locally in Docker is the fastest way to develop and test AL extensions without needing a cloud sandbox.

## Prerequisites

- **Docker Desktop** for Windows (with Windows containers)
- **PowerShell 5.1+**
- **BcContainerHelper** PowerShell module
- At least 8GB RAM (16GB recommended)

## Install BcContainerHelper

```powershell
Install-Module BcContainerHelper -Force
Import-Module BcContainerHelper
```

## Create a BC Container

```powershell
$params = @{
  containerName      = 'bcdev'
  imageName          = 'mcr.microsoft.com/businesscentral:sandbox'
  accept_eula        = $true
  accept_outdated    = $true
  auth               = 'UserPassword'
  credential         = (New-Object PSCredential 'admin',
                        (ConvertTo-SecureString 'Password1!' -AsPlainText -Force))
  updateHosts        = $true
  licenseFile        = 'C:\bc\license.flf'
}

New-BcContainer @params
```

## Useful BcContainerHelper Commands

```powershell
# Publish an extension
Publish-BcContainerApp -containerName 'bcdev' `
  -appFile '.\output\MyApp.app' `
  -skipVerification

# Run AL tests
Run-TestsInBcContainer -containerName 'bcdev' `
  -extensionId (Get-BcContainerAppInfo 'bcdev' | 
    Where-Object { $_.Name -eq 'MyApp' }).AppId

# Get container logs
Get-BcContainerEventLog -containerName 'bcdev'
```

## Connect VS Code to Your Container

Update your `launch.json`:
```json
{
  "server": "http://bcdev",
  "authentication": "UserPassword",
  "credential": {
    "userName": "admin",
    "password": "Password1!"
  }
}
```

## Troubleshooting Tips

- **Container won't start?** Check Windows container mode in Docker Desktop
- **License errors?** Ensure your `.flf` license file is for the correct BC version
- **Slow startup?** First pull of the image takes 10-20 minutes ÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂ subsequent restarts are fast
